description: From Middle English park, from Old French parc (“livestock pen”), from Medieval Latin parcus, parricus, from Frankish *parrik (“enclosure, pen”), from Proto-Germanic *parrukaz (“enclosure, fence”). Cognate with Dutch perk (“enclosure; flowerbed”), Old High German pfarrih, pferrih (“enclosure, pen”), Old English pearroc (“enclosure”) (whence modern English paddock), Old Norse parrak, parak (“enclosure, pen; distress, anxiety”), Icelandic parraka (“to keep pent in, under restraint and coercion”). More at parrock, paddock.

definitionGroups.group: An area of land set aside for environment preservation or recreation.

entries.meaning: A tract of ground kept in its natural state, about or adjacent to a residence, such as for the preservation of game, for walking, riding, or the like.
examples: While in the park I sing, the listening deer / Attend my passion, and forget to fear.

entries.meaning: A piece of ground in or near a city or town, enclosed and kept for ornament and recreation.
examples: Hyde Park in London;  Central Park in New York

entries.meaning: An enclosed parcel of land stocked with animals for hunting, which one may have by prescription or royal grant.
(US) A wide, flat-bottomed valley in a mountainous region.

definitionGroups.group: An area used for specific purposes.

entries.meaning: An open space occupied by or reserved for vehicles, matériel or stores.
examples: a wagon park;   an artillery park

entries.meaning: A partially enclosed basin in which oysters are grown.
An area zoned for a particular (industrial or commercial) purpose.
examples: business park;  industrial park;  science park

entries.meaning: An area on which a sporting match is played; (soccer) a pitch.
(UK) An inventory of matériel.
examples: A country's tank park or artillery park.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, colloquial) A space in which to leave a car; a parking space.
examples: We got to the 9th Ward and as luck would have it I found a park for my bro′s car right out the front.

verbs.description: park (third-person singular simple present parks, present participle parking, simple past and past participle parked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bring (something such as a vehicle) to a halt or store in a specified place.
examples: You can park the car in front of the house.
I parked the drive heads of my hard disk before travelling with my laptop.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To defer (a matter) until a later date.
examples: Let's park that until next week's meeting.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bring together in a park, or compact body.
examples: to park artillery, wagons, automobiles, etc.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To enclose in a park, or as in a park.
(transitive, baseball) To hit a home run; to hit the ball out of the park.
(intransitive, slang) To engage in romantic or sexual activities inside a nonmoving vehicle that was driven to a suitable spot for that purpose.
examples: They stopped at a romantic overlook, shut off the engine, and parked.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal, sometimes reflexive) To sit, recline, or put, especially in a manner suggesting an intent to remain for some time.
examples: He came in and parked himself in our living room.
Park your bags in the hall.

entries.meaning: (transitive, finance) To invest money temporarily in an investment instrument considered to relatively free of risk, especially while awaiting other opportunities.
examples: We decided to park our money in a safe, stable, low-yield bond fund until market conditions improve.

entries.meaning: (Internet) To register a domain name, but make no use of it (See domain parking)
(transitive, oyster culture) To enclose in a park, or partially enclosed basin.
(intransitive, dated) To promenade or drive in a park.
(intransitive, dated, of horses) To display style or gait on a park drive.
